comments.author: Liz @ EatingPlaces
comments.content: I love these! When we make them we set up an assembly line with different people at each station. So yummy and perfect for the summer. A note about your serving sizes - I've been known to have 5 or 6 as a meal, but I might just like them a little too much ;)

comments.author: Talya B
comments.content: Once you've got the hang of these, they can be made very quickly. I made a very similar version today, for my lunch and my kids' packed lunches. I made peanut sauce and prepped yesterday evening, soaked the (mung bean) vermicelli while I had a shower this morning, assembled the kids' rolls while they had breakfast and mine in my lunchbreak. And we often have them for a weeknight dinner - I prep while everyone does homework, but we all roll our own at the table as we eat. Healthy, tasty and fun. I buy tofu already fried.

comments.author: John
comments.content:
I love these things. And I like you dipping sauce recipe -- definitely will get added to our list of things to make. This recipe is also one where too many cooks is a good thing -- the prep work can be easily done by 4 or 5 people working together, although it helps to have a couple of cutting boards. And the assembly is similar -- much easier with several hands. 

When I make these, I do it on a plate that's a little larger than the wrapper. The plate ends up wet, which helps soften the wrappers, but also helps contain the mess. I also use moderately warm water rather than hot, and it seems to work fine. 

Finally, in our household we like to add either shredded basil or whole thai-basil leaves, perhaps as an alternative to the mint that you use.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Very good point about letting everyone roll their own at the table. Good fun, and it makes it a lot faster too. Plus with kids they can customize which ingredients they like, which is always a plus.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: The assembly line is a good approach too! If you have enough hands to make short work of the job, that is all to the good. Yeah - I could probably eat that many and call it dinner too.
